threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I've been analyzing this scene for years. At first, I just couldn't understand it. Why did Isayama do it? Wasn't he the master of storytelling? A mangaka that I've been devotedly following for near a decade? Why do this to one of his most beloved and idolized characters? I have sat in my room, staring at this image. Sure, Jean and Mikasa's child was a tough pill to swallow. Historia and the farmer's child too. But this image is what truly drew my attention for years since it came out. Why did he do it.
And finally after years of this rumination, I believe I finally have my answer. Why he made this infamous scene. Isayama understood that many saw Eren as an extension of themselves. That we were these "cool badasses" that could do anything when pushed to it. So he had that seed grow in ours minds... And then he exposed us for what we truly were.
Don't know what I mean? Let me further explain. Whenever anyone on /a/ or some edgy redditor said "Omg Eren is literally us" Pic related is what we truly meant. Though we pretend to be cool and know-it-alls, in the end, we whined like a baby when the going got tough, and thats exactly what happened to Eren in this scene. Isayama made this scene to expose us.
We weren't the badass sigma male that did whatever he wanted and fucked every bitch. Don't you remember on how EVERY poster broke down when this chapter came out?
Isayama was just revealing the people that we (Eren) truly were.

Crybabies.

Simply masterful.

>>245639704
call it whatever you want, for me it's more about the difference between stories vs. real life. i mean i could imagine irl even if one of her friends showed up and saw what was going on, they might not necessarily be willing to put themselves in harms way to help her. or if they did, maybe the guy pulls out a knife or gun and shoots/stabs the other student before going back to the raping. all sorts of shit like that is more realistic. in real life the bad guys don't always lose, in fact there are people like jimmy seville who got away with it for their whole lives and were essentially worshipped as pillars of the community despite all the terrible shit they did and got away with.

i guess the point im trying to make about this is that it's like the idea some comedian had about signs. if there's a sign that says "don't do X", it means someone DID do X, and there was probably litigation over it and that's why there's a sign there now. like "CAUTION: Coffee is HOT" is on coffee cups at McDonalds because some guy spilled it on his junk and sued them, so now they need the sign there. or "Don't drink gasoline" at the gas station: guess what, someone probably drank gasoline and sued because they didn't know they couldn't.

So, from now on, I encourage anons to watch animes and think about this. The same way you'd look at any sign for the rest of your life and imagine someone doing the bad thing no matter how dumb it is. It's fun to imagine how the scenes would really play out in a realistic setting where characters didn't have plot armor and the like. you know what i mean?

To sum it up: Sensei is not a teacher but an exorcist, the students were either hired actors or proxies for the spirits that were being exorcised. The characters we saw for the past 299 chapters were roles the proxies acted out, i.e. the spirits of the Showa girls, that slowly assimilated with their hosts. Now that they got to graduate posthumously, the Showa girls moved on and left their hosts behind.
>Kiri no longer plays the role of the hikkikomori and thus goes outside
>Matoi no longer plays the role of the stalker and thus wears her normal seifuku
>Meru no longer plays the role of Merupapa's daughter, that's why he thanks her here >>245575110
